content:
Nicely done !

However I found a small issue : there is a trailing whitespace at the end of the second line of "Big with few edges" Validator.

I'm glad I have access to the contribution, the "bad format" error on
points[i] = stdin.readLineSync().split(' ').map(int.parse).toList();
might have eluded me for a while !
It just occurred to me you had a call to abs() in your solution despite your inputs being directed. Would it by any chance be related to an undebugged overflow issue? :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is well-planned and adjusted to suit everyone
Well written puzzle @Fluxor
good

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because 32 bits ought to be enough for everyone.

Heya,

I think your validator 3 “Big with few edges” is incorrect: it overflows a 32-bit int in the 3rd edge (between the two last vertices) in the shoelace formula; the correct answer ought to be 914829094.

I'm torn on the Correct way out. Easy: swap test and validator. But then many are going to wonder why they can't solve test 3.

I'd suggest either adding explicit int64 cases, or trimming down all cases to "int32- compatible", with adjusted constraints.

Hi.
Good idea. I approved, but if you could bring these 2 precisions on assumptions made on the input, it would be better :
1) vertices could not intersect each others
2) polygon is closed 

For both users, it is evident, but explicit is better than implicit.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: After discussion, approved

Hi
Not bad, not bad

My issues:
- Even your solution is 50-50 when it times out, or not on the Big Flower Bed try. It is very around the time limit, and that can cause some frustrating "I don't know, why it's not working, and working at once" situations.
- Hard... Meh... Medium maybe. I mean, it's basically elementary school math.
- I don't really like when it is written for some specific language libraries, but that's just my taste.

If you solve the first two, you get an approve from me.
Nice and simple, not overthought. I like it.
Just a formal remark: in the documentation it is written that you should not address the reader directly. (https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/contribution-guidelines)

Very nice and original puzzle :-).
The two ascii-art example in the statement are very helpfull and beautiful.

There is a typo in second item of the list below “Example”: “with with .”.
nice

I completely understood the problem and what we need to do..! Great Explanation there, but for a beginner like me it's seriously difficult to deduce an idea to solve it and convert to the corresponding code...

Nice puzzle, like it.

But it's not clear from the statemant how flower beds vertices are connected.

And also it's not clear when flower spot aren't useble for planting. I mean, is flower spots are squeare shaped, and we shouldn't use it if flower bed boundary crosses the square? Or flower is a point and we can plant it if the point inside a flower bad? Or even flowers are circles and we souldn't use spots when flower bed boundary crosses the circle?

Nice problem, very well set! Feedback:

* "very hard" seems a bit much: it's two google searches away to deduce a smart solution (say medium), or feasible with an O(N*min(deltaX,deltaY)) scanning one (medium-hard).

* we've had this debate recently on another puzzle: "counter-clockwise" isn't directly meaningful if there isn't a centroid from which all vertex progression can be seen as in the same direction (in a word, a convex poloygon). I understand why you put that information in, but I fear it conveys a wrong idea when all it helps with is skipping an abs operation. I'm not sure I have a "great" improvement suggestion here :(

* I've re-read 3 times and I still haven't convinced myself that the obvious "it's all on the standard integral orthonormal lattice" follows from the statement. It's kind of ok if it doesn't, the test cases are there, but it's more highly classy if it does.

* I think part of the confusion comes from your strings reifying the grid (IIUC), while a possibly more natural interpretation of "hammering poles and stretching strings" would be to mark the perimeter. Especially when that's the one shown in the diagrams.

Still, great job, very fine work with the diagrams!

Very well written, great job!
Remove '[[' around [[Line 1]] - it's not an input variable

Love your ascii art example :-)
Hey do you have any rules about how far apart horizontally? e.g. if the top and bottom apexes were only 1 apart then would the same number of flowers be planted?
 o oo
 o oo
 o oo
ooooo
ooooo
oooo
ooooo
ooooo
You should rename grid intersections to something more meaningful, planting spots maybe. Seems like a good puzzle otherwise.
Thanks for your feedback, I have updated the description accordingly.

I am not sure to understand what the top and bottom apexes are in your example.
If you mean moving vertex (2,2) on (1,2), it would indeed give the same result.

There is no restriction about distances between vertices.
For example,  (0, 0), (1, 0), (1, 1), (0,1) is a valid flower bed in which one can put no flower at all, just like (0, 0), (1, 0), (0, 500000).

You can try and draw example 2 (Small with many edges). They are small enough to fit in a sheet of paper, and will give you a good feeling about possible shapes.
Nice catch! This is fixed. Thanks!

Nice one, very compact.
I have added it and put it as a second example.

Hi
Thanks a lot for your feedback.

I made a few adjustments:
- difficulty decreased
- removed the note about vertices being sorted counter-clockwise. BTW I think it may still make sense for non-convex polygons in a 2D plane as there is an homeomorphic transformation into a circle, but I am no topology expert ;-)
- I rephrased the last note into " flower bed vertices are always on potential planting spots (their coordinates are <<integers>>)" to try and clarify

When you get more experience in problem solving, you will start thinking about problems differently.
For example, a common trick with _counting_ problems is to count or compute something else (which is easier to count or compute) and that may be related, and then search for a relation.
In this case an obvious candidate is the area, so you may want to search for a relation between the number of points inside a polygon and its area. If this does not ring a bell, remember that google is your friend!.

Note: this approach works as well for my other submission ("The lost files")

Thanks.
I fixed the typo.

Hi,
Thanks for your feedback , I was not aware of this.
I adjusted the the description not to address the reader directly.

I added a note about edges not crossing each others.
For your second point, I think that is is already embedded in the definition of a polygon: 
an "open polygon" would not be a polygon.

Nice catch!
I will trim down all cases to make them int32 compatible, not to penalize langages with crapy 64 bits computation support.

It is because the polygon area is signed with the sign depending on the order of the vertices (CW or CCW). 
I did not remember the sign and was too lazy to check, so I simply called fabs() 
So there is one chance out of two that this call has no effect :-D
Thanks. I fixed the input.
Let me know. I'll approve then.

Done.
 - I recucced by factor ~10 all input of both UI test and validator for tests 3 and 4. Since 10000^2 < 2^30-1, overflow is not possible anymore
- I ran all tests against both 64bits and 32bits versions of my solution and checked that I get the same result.
- I updated the constraints accordingly.
As well, note that I did not enable any compiler optimization on purpose, to allow using "slower" languages
Hi what I meant, was that your solution was heavy relying on the polygon stuff in C++, and that  is not available in every language. But as I said: that's my taste. Approved :)

Well, if you read my solution carefully, you will notice that it does not rely on any built-in polygon-stuffs (which unfortunately do not even exist in the C++ language).
The variable iPolygon is of type std::vector, which is equivalent to a generic list or array in other languages.
The vertices are of type std::pair, which is equivalent to  generic tuples of size 2 in other languages.
=> the only data structures involved here are tuples and lists.

And the only functions called are gcd (greatest common divisor), fabs (float absolute value), and round (to round float value to nearest integer).  So there is nothing polygon-specific at all :-)

Oh, don't get me wrong, I do think the ccw-ness makes sense "globally" :) I merely think making the phrasing mathematically sound wouldn't be enough of a benefit to make up for the heavier language. Especially in the main statement.
Wow, you made it look even nicer, great work! :D
Oh I see now, the .'s in your ascii art example are the integer points, so your example already had top and bottom vertices 1 apart just like I was trying to say. :-)
